report_title: Industry Report on Bankruptcy Lawyers & Attorneys
executive_summary: The industry performed more or less as expected from 2020 through 2024. As a rule, bankruptcy lawyers share an inverse relationship with the economy's overall health. Revenue has consistently declined since its peak in 2017, except for a slight growth in 2019 just before the pandemic. Despite the cessation of business activity in 2020, a return to work in 2021 fueled by government incentives created a hostile environment for bankruptcy lawyers; business was booming, and the industry was hurting. Revenue is expected to shrink at a CAGR of 3.8% through the end of 2024 to reach $6.1 billion, including a depression of 0.5% in 2024 alone. Profit has fallen too, accounting for an expected 20.3% of revenue in 2024, down from 21.3% in 2019

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Chapter 11 Bankruptcies Drive Industry Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Chapter 11 bankruptcy, also known as reorganization bankruptcy, generates the most revenue for bankruptcy lawyers and accounts for the vast majority of litigation. Litigation fees for Chapter 11 bankruptcy are substantially higher than other chapters of bankruptcy, as Chapter 11 involves reorganization and debt repayment plans that are meticulously constructed, often for businesses with millions of dollars of assets.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Individual Bankruptcy Cases Constitute Most Bankruptcy Cases
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Most consumer bankruptcy filings come from middle income, employed individuals that are aged 45 to 54. future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Industry Revenue Performance Tied to Recovery Rate of the Economy
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry will continue to share an inverse relationship with the economy's overall health. As post-COVID expansion cools, the industry will perform more favorably. Rising interest rates in 2023 have fueled demand for bankruptcy lawyers from individuals and small businesses. Rates are expected to stagnate or gain only marginally, indicating nominal industry performance through the end of 2029.

Chapter 9 bankruptcy, which permits municipalities to file bankruptcy and reorganize, may become more prevalent as federal and local governments continue to battle budget cuts in the wake of the pandemic. There have only been 33 instances of Chapter 9 bankruptcy between 2001 and May 2020, with Detroit being the largest municipality to file in recent years. Still, Chapter 9 bankruptcy filings are likely to be an additional source of revenue for bankruptcy lawyers, thanks to the unprecedented decline in revenue at both a macroeconomic and microeconomic level.

market_segmentation.segment: Companies with assets less than 100.0 million
market_segmentation.segment_description: Smaller businesses file for bankruptcy to rectify significant debt or operational issues, or seek protection and reorganization. These businesses file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Bankruptcy lawyers help in evaluating the best course of action based on a business's specific circumstances.

Individuals file for bankruptcy for a variety of reasons. Many individuals live paycheck-to-paycheck during times of economic strife. Individuals typically file for Chapter 7 or Chapter 13 bankruptcy. Individuals with complex finances may file for Chapter 11, though these cases are rare.

market_segmentation.segment: Companies with assets more than $1.0 billion
market_segmentation.segment_description: Large companies may file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in times of economic downturn. Often considered "too big to fail", these companies buckle under their own weight and turn to bankruptcy as a solution. High profile companies that have filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy since the turn of the century include Enron Corporation, WorldCom, General Motors, Toys R Us, Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) and Hertz Global Holdings Inc. These filings prove the most lucrative for bankruptcy lawyers as these companies have massive portfolios that require significant time, energy and money to litigate.
